<co-content><text>First of all, I would like to thank everyone involved in creating the specialization - the lecturers, the actors in the capstone simulation, and the team doing all the other work: I am sure that there were so many others involved in making the courses happen. You have done a great job, and I really enjoyed my experience with the specialization. </text><text>I was acquainted with the Agile methodology before the course (although on a surface level), and have even used several instruments before in my digital agency, but I never had a chance to dive into it and learn how important it is to use all the tools in a coordinated and sustainable way. I learned a lot of new instruments during the courses, and managed to make my existing knowledge more systematic. </text><text>The favorite part of the experience was the capstone project, it is very nice to see how all the theory gets real and how important all parts of the projects are, especially those, which are usually ignored because the lack of time (unit/acceptance tests, documentation, retrospective meetings). I also liked the quizzes in the first five courses, they really helped to review the new knowledge and arrange the information in a way which makes it easier to remember certain things better. </text><text>I am grateful for the certain flexibility of the courses - I joined the specialization very late, and in order to make it to the Capstone sign up deadline, I had to go over most of the courses in a very short amount of time, and managed to do it with the help of the discussion forums (fellow students kindly doing peer reviews even after they completed the assignments). On the other hand, I managed to complete the Capstone few weeks earlier, I loved that everyone can more or less follow their own speed in the courses. </text><text>There are things which can be improved, of course: for instance, I personally would love to have more assignments, and more difficult ones, especially in the Capstone project. Instead, I could sometimes feel that the assignments became easier closer to the end of the course, some of them being very similar to the previous ones. I also believe, that it would be great not to have only peer reviews, but also at least one review on each assignment from an experienced professional. Especially the comments sections, which mostly consisted of just a few words, rather than a more profound feedback. I also liked the assignments which had certain templates or suggested the tools to use, it helped to save the time on creating the templates on your own, and gave more time to focus on the quality of content provided. The templates would also be a great asset for the course graduates in the future, I think this could be a good and highly valued improvement in future Capstone projects. </text><text>Overall the experience was great, I am sure that the knowledge and some skills gained during the 6 courses will be helpful in the future, and I will recommend the course to those who may potentially be interested. </text><text>Thanks again for the hard work on the specialization, it’s definitely appreciated!</text></co-content>

discussion_question_details: \\nWhat were some of your favourite parts of the specialization? Overall, I think I benefited from the specialization in that I have a new vocabulary to help me think and talk about Product Management. As I already work in product management, I found that I produced many of the work products that the course walked me through, but the products went by different names, and they looked with different software reporting tools. This course helped me know about my work in different terms.I also have to commend Morgan and the rest of the SPM staff for their responsiveness to my questions. I’ve read about the challenges in trying to engage an online MOOC community, and I think you all did a great job.\\nThe presenters, Alexa, Josh, Kat, Lisa and Daniel were great actors and actresses for the part. \\nWhat could we improve to make the specialization better? I found that the 'Client Needs and Software Requirements' module to be the most painful of the Specialization, especially the assignment with ambiguous requirements. A product manager should know to probe a client for further details. With that assignment, you can’t further probe a customer because it’s a one way dialogue through text.I think something that was missing entirely from the course was working with UX / Design. In my experience, UX / Design teams work at a different cadence than back end developers. That interaction, of Product Manager-and-Design team, was missing.I felt as though requirements elicitation, or customer development (a la Steve Blank) wasn’t explored as much as I would have liked. It is a deep topic and can probably span several modules or be its own course. For the amount of time and energy I spend trying to ‘get in front of customers’ I felt this specialization didn’t stress its importance enough.\\n\\nHow has this specialization helped you? Where do you think this specialization will take you?I already work in Product Management and intended to take this specialization for my own edification. I didn’t anticipate that I would be job searching while taking this course.Since I’ve only worked as a Product Manager in one other company, taking this course, in particular the Capstone, gave me the perspective of what it could be like working at another company.When I interviewed, one company’s CTOs had asked me, “So, you’re a student at the University of Alberta?” I explained to him that as a Product Manager, I’m constantly learning, constantly trying to hone my skills. This specialization made me stand out amongst other candidates as the company extended an offer of employment to me. ( I declined it for a different Product Owner opportunity :) ).Overall, the Software Product Management Course acts as a comprehensive introduction to the field. The course exceeded my expectations in that I found it far more engaging and thorough than trying to piece together my own curriculum online and through books.\\nMany thanks to the SPM staff and my fellow classmates.\\nCheers,Lino

discussion_question_title: Awesome Capstone Course - great learning experience
discussion_question_details: <co-content><text>The Capstone Software Product Management course surpassed my expectations and had a very practical, yet insightful training engagement sequence, full of engagement props and down-to-earth, easy to understand learning material.  \\n</text><text>For instance, the live video engagements with people (developers and client stakeholders), with simulated inclusion of me the student in close-to real meeting interactions was a great approach, as I was able to learn more about sprint planning, daily stand-up’s and sprint review events.  The review and addition of requirements, the negotiation of user stories and the assignment of priorities was very insightful as an outside listener because it highlighted two key aspect of importance: face-to-face team communication and the active, constant engagements that takes place in these events.\\n</text><text>The interactive tool which aided in the creation of the Release Plans was a great inclusion since it allowed the student to look at a Product Catalog, see the risk and priorities of each user story, the related tasks dependencies, understand sprint velocity concept and use these as criterion to assign the user stories to a print.  This was a great innovative learning artifact.\\n</text><text>A fun aspect was building the Release and Iteration Burndown Charts.  This was not my first experience in building charts with Excel, however, was my first in building, interpreting and understanding burndown charts.  Understanding velocity and team performance was a key learning activity.\\n</text><text>Another great learning aspect was the interaction with my classmates as there were many different learning approaches and suggestions through the Review Your Peers assignments.\\n</text><text>Overall, what was learned during the individual training courses was brought to life during the capstone allowing me to go back to prior course reading material to review and better understand the different capstone assignments.\\n</text><text>This was not my first introduction to Agile and Scrum, however, the entire Software Product Management program, and especially the capstone was where I believe I have gained the most knowledge.   I would have liked to learn a bit more about the engineering aspects of Agile and Scrum.\\n</text><text>What can be done better: a bit more attention on the how-to aspect of the burndown chart.  There were small issues in the wording of assignment questions and their relationship to the actual class material provided to the student.  In the short 6 weeks this was a fantastic class and nothing to come to mind in terms of major or even minor improvements.  \\n</text><text>Overall, this was an Excellent capstone course in which I learned quite a bit while enjoying it at the same time.</text><text>A special thank you and congratulations to the University of Alberta, Coursera and the staff for putting together this important program.</text><text>Best regards,</text><text>Eugenio</text><text>\\n</text></co-content>

discussion_question_title: Thanks for an awesome learning experience !!
discussion_question_details: I would like to thank, the Coursera and team, and all my colleagues\\nfor a wonderful experience learning more about software product management. Artefacts- \\nI enjoyed creating all the assignment artifacts, in particular I enjoyed these two:o \\nWireframes – I had fun creating the wireframes,\\nand also enjoyed seeing the creations that my colleagues had created.o \\nBurndown Chart, I struggled with the concept of\\nthe burn down charts, but through practice, reading the course material again\\nand asking questions, I feel confident that burndown charts will become\\ningrained in my daily activities. Was the “project”\\na success?I absolutely loved this course. I have used and will continue to use\\neverything that I have learned over the course duration.Want went well?1. \\nThe course material is very relevant to agile development\\ntoday.2. \\nThe course is well paced; there were never too many\\nvideos or assignments.3. \\nThe actors were excellent; the story was a great\\nreal life example. 4. \\nThe practical assignments forced me s to think\\nand to simulate a real life scenario.5. \\nI found that the peer reviews were an excellent\\nway to learn, I experienced examples of answers that were better than mine, and\\nsome where clear mistakes would made. But having the opportunity to see and\\nobserve, really did help re-inforce the answers.6. \\nI enjoyed all the courses, but especially from\\nthe 3rd course, when we started doing the real life practical\\nassignments. What did I learn?I learned so much, but the key items that have made a real\\nimpact to my daily work are:- \\nLearning the various different development process\\nmodels and how each project may call for a different process model, depending\\non the project circumstances.- \\nThe link between, process, phases, activates and\\ntasks. - \\nI learned the importance of prototyping, and the\\nimportance of selecting the right type of\\nprototype according to the needs of the project. There are a few projects I have\\nbeen on; that I believe would have ended more positively, if a basic wireframe\\nprototype had been drawn upfront.- \\nThe meaning of delivering the right product, done\\nright and managed right.- \\nThe entire clients’ needs and requirements\\ncourse, taught me the difference between eliciting requirements vs to just getting requirements, as well as the skill to\\ndocument the requirements correctly and the importance of removing all ambiguity.- \\nThe planning tools such as release plans and internal\\nplans and the associated burndown charts are an effective way to know the state\\nof my projects and to implement contingency plans as soon as a slippage is\\nforeseen.- \\nI learned that when it comes to engaging with\\npeople and projects, there is not only one right way, each of us are unique and\\nhave different ways of doing things, however, as long as the right principles\\nand methods are applied, we will all achieve success. What would I do differently?1. \\nI would have liked to have spent more time on my\\nassignments, working on a difficult project over the course period; I only\\nstarted each week on a Saturday / Sunday.It would be more helpful, if I spread the\\nvideos and tasks over a week.2. \\nPerhaps, a suggestion for the future, in the\\ncourse, it is mentioned that a product managers role comprises of different\\nroles, it would be nice if there was a linked course that contained the\\nmarketing, and business side of this\\nfunction.3. \\nAt the outset, there was quite a bit of\\nconfusion around the creation of the backlog (list of user stories). It would\\nhave been great if we had received a list of suggested / or recommended users\\nstories as an example so that we can learn a correct way to ensure we get the\\nright requirements, documented correctly. 4. \\nI found that sometimes the grading did not\\nreflect whether the assignment was 100% correct. There were times when there\\nwere mistakes, but the questions did not reveal the mistakes, as they focused\\non a limited set of questions. Once again, thanks to everyone involved for a totally awesome\\nexperience!! Kind regards \\nKathleen
